1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:11): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: You don't have a butcher nearby?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:12): argument in favour of turning the web from using javascript to using bytecode as the basic language that browsers execute:
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:12): > Bytecode contains no unnecessary bytes. No spaces, no line-endings, no tabs. Only opcodes that do precisely one thing, and only that.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:13): indeed
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:14): see bytecode has no whitespace so there are going to be fewer bugs
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:14): nods encouragingly
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (22:14): because opcodes in dynamic languages don't ever do more than one thing (err)
8925426ae91d6282f262eb2ee108bdc0 (22:14): Is THAT how that works? hahah
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:14): Was there more context that suggests this meant "less bugs"?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:14): yeah, long e-mail
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:14): Or was it just an argument that bytecode is smaller?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:14): no, it was an argument that browser vendors wouldn't introduce as many bugs in their bytecode processor as they do in their JS processor
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:15): Oh.  That's retarded.
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (22:15): How about we only allow certified programmers to publish on the web? Seems like a good way to prevent bugs
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:15): dunno about retarded. Ignorant, though, yes.
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (22:15): as if most interop problems center around the JS engine
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (22:15): javascript is possibly the simplest, most obvious language in common use today
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (22:16): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6, I'm not sure JS implementers would agree with that ;)
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (22:16): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, surely bugs are only in old code, and not in new?
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (22:16): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81: language complexity and optimized runtime complexity are entirely different things :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:17): another argument in that e-mail: "bytecode opcodes often translate 1-on-1 to target machine instructions"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:17): is reminded of the latest "how i met your mother" episode ("oh, honey...")
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (22:17): who's trolling hixie, i wonder
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:17): Everyone knows that native machine code has no bugs.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:23): Oh, so you give them the animal to slaughter?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:23): I've never seen a butcher who actually does the killing themselves.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:24): is confused
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:24): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: Abatoirs do the slaughtering
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:24): In my experience, "butcher" is more or less interchangeable with "meat-seller".
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:24): ...No, a butcher has a bunch of (dead) animals, and they'll cut it down.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:24): Butchers cut up the carcass
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:24): My dictionary says it can mean both.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:24): Get a better dictionary.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:24): And an abattoir is a slaughterhouse, not a slaughterer.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:25): What does your dictionary say, then?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:25): I don't have one.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:25): Right, the people at the slaughterhouse don't have a special name afaik
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:25): So you rely on what, making stuff up?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:25): "slaughterers"
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:25): It's worked so far!
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:25): All my definitions are cromulent.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:26): Well yes, if you are a radical egan they are probably "murderers" or something
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (22:26): It worked out with frex,frex

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:26): is probably confused in part because 90% of the discussion he's been part of regarding the slaughter of animals is specifically in the context of kosher food, which might be different and where some of the terminology is in Hebrew or Yiddish or Aramaic
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:26): I didn't invent that one, to be fair.

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:27): I assume it's so we can experiment with it first.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:27): Google Search can't experiment?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:27): I thought they experiment all over the place.
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (22:28): Oh no, Google will save which sites we dislike!

06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (22:28): they've had (on and off) the little "x" to hide individual results in pages, which is pretty useless--i've wished many times that would apply to a whole domain

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:28): Which is quite exciting

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:28): Oh man, I should trigger those purposely.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:28): does the same.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:29): So I'll let that one be.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:29): (until I see it)

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:29): I find that experts-exchange is roughly as useful as other medium-tier things, once you use Stylish to hide all the bullshit they put before the actual answer.
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (22:29): i'm habitually doing site:*.w3.org when i'm doing w3-related searches now, specifically to avoid w3schools
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:30): Yeah, once you know that you can scroll down to get the answer, it's not so bad.
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (22:30): even adding "w3" to a search still lands w3schools first
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:30): I'm pretty sure they used to actually cloak the answer somehow, though.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:30): But they stopped at some point.
